**MAT 23:2**: _(Grade 75.8)_

**Source**:  
> λέγων· ἐπὶ τῆς Μωσέως καθέδρας ἐκάθισαν οἱ γραμματεῖς καὶ οἱ Φαρισαῖοι.  
(Translation: Saying, "The scribes and the Pharisees sit on Moses' seat.")

**Translation**:  
> «¡Cualquiera que ve a estos escribas y fariseos creando leyes se creerá que son “Moisés en persona”!  
(Translation: "Anyone who sees these scribes and Pharisees creating laws will believe that they are 'Moses in person'!")

**Suggested Translation**:  
> «Los escribas y fariseos se han sentado en la silla de Moisés.»  
(Translation: "The scribes and Pharisees have sat on the seat of Moses.")

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 23:2 generally seeks to make the biblical text accessible for modern Spanish speakers. However, multiple reviewers expressed concerns regarding the accuracy of the phrase "Cualquiera que ve a estos escribas y fariseos creando leyes se creerá que son 'Moisés en persona'" ("Anyone who sees these scribes and Pharisees creating laws will believe that they are 'Moses in person'"), which introduces an informal interpretation that detracts from the original Greek text's focus on the authority of the scribes and Pharisees sitting in Moses' seat, implying they create laws rather than simply holding a position of authority to teach the Law. A more conservative and literal translation, such as "los escribas y fariseos han tomado asiento en la cátedra de Moisés" ("the scribes and Pharisees have taken their seat in the chair of Moses"), would better reflect the serious nature of Jesus' teaching and the intended reverence of the original scripture. Overall, while the translation attempts to engage a Latin American audience, it requires adjustments to maintain theological integrity and accurately convey the essence of the biblical message.

**MAT 22:3**: _(Grade 78.3)_

**Source**:  
> καὶ ἀπέστειλε τοὺς δούλους αὐτοῦ καλέσαι τοὺς κεκλημένους εἰς τοὺς γάμους, καὶ οὐκ ἤθελον ἐλθεῖν. (And he sent his servants to call those who were invited to the wedding, but they did not want to come.)  

**Translation**:  
> Envió muchísimas invitaciones, y cuando el banquete estuvo listo, mandó un mensajero a notificar a los convidados que ya podían ir. ¡Pero nadie fue! (He sent many invitations, and when the banquet was ready, he sent a messenger to notify the guests that they could go. But nobody went!)  

**Suggested Translation**:  
> «Envió a sus siervos a invitar a los que estaban invitados a la boda, pero no quisieron venir.» (He sent his servants to invite those who were invited to the wedding, but they did not want to come.)  

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 22:3 demonstrates a commendable effort to make the biblical text accessible for contemporary Spanish-speaking audiences, particularly in Latin America. However, several reviewers noted that the phrase "Envió muchísimas invitaciones" (He sent many invitations) strays from the original Greek text, which emphasizes the singular invitation extended by the king rather than a multitude. Additionally, the expression "¡Pero nadie fue!" (But nobody went!) may oversimplify the serious implications of the invited guests' rejection, which could be better captured with a more literal rendering like "no quisieron venir" (they did not want to come). The reviews collectively highlight the need for a balance between modern language accessibility and fidelity to the original scripture's meaning and weight. While the intent to engage the audience is evident, striving for precision and maintaining the gravity of the message is crucial. The translation is effective overall but has room for improvement in accurately reflecting the original text's nuances.

**MAT 10:34**: _(Grade 79.2)_

**Source**:
> Μὴ νομίσητε ὅτι ἦλθον βαλεῖν εἰρήνην ἐπὶ τὴν γῆν· οὐκ ἦλθον βαλεῖν εἰρήνην, ἀλλὰ μάχαιραν.  
(Matthew 10:34: "Do not think that I have come to bring peace to the earth; I have not come to bring peace, but a sword.")

**Translation**:
> No crean que vine a traer paz a la tierra. ¡Vine a traer guerras!;  
(Don't think that I came to bring peace to the earth. I came to bring wars!)

**Suggested Translation**:
> No piensen que he venido a traer paz a la tierra; no he venido a traer paz, sino división.  
(Don't think that I have come to bring peace to the earth; I have not come to bring peace, but division.)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 10:34 generally reflects the original Greek text, but it faces criticism primarily for the use of the term 'guerras' (wars). Multiple reviewers note that this word does not accurately convey the metaphorical implications of the original Greek word 'μάχαιραν' (sword), which signifies division and conflict rather than literal warfare. The suggestion to use 'división' (division) or 'espada' (sword) aligns better with the intention of Jesus' message about the cost of discipleship and the potential for division among families due to loyalty to Him. While the translation is modern and accessible, careful consideration of word choice is essential to preserve theological meaning and clarity. Overall, the translation captures the provocative nature of Christ's statement but could be improved for precision and fidelity to the biblical context.

**MAT 23:14**: _(Grade 79.2)_

> Οὐαὶ ὑμῖν, γραμματεῖς καὶ Φαρισαῖοι ὑποκριταί, ὅτι κλείετε τὴν βασιλείαν τῶν οὐρανῶν ἔμπροσθεν τῶν ἀνθρώπων· ὑμεῖς γὰρ οὐκ εἰσέρχεσθε, οὐδὲ τοὺς εἰσερχομένους ἀφίετε εἰσελθεῖν. **Translation**:
> ¡Ay de ustedes, escribas y fariseos hipócritas, que por un lado hacen oraciones larguísimas en las calles y por el otro les roban las casas a las viudas! ¡Hipócritas! (Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you make long prayers at length while robbing widows' houses!)

**Suggested Translation**:
> ¡Ay de ustedes, escribas y fariseos hipócritas, que cierran la puerta del reino de los cielos delante de los hombres! Porque ustedes no entran, ni dejan entrar a los que quieren. The translation of MAT 23:14 effectively conveys the essence and condemnation of hypocrisy among the religious leaders. The recommendations include rephrasing to better align with the original meaning, emphasizing the shutting of the kingdom rather than adding accusations not stated in the source. Overall, while the style is modern and accessible, there is a significant need for greater fidelity to the original scripture's intent, affecting clarity and accuracy.

**MAT 24:34**: _(Grade 79.2)_

**Source**:

**Translation**:

**Suggested Translation**:
> Esta generación no pasará hasta que todas estas cosas sucedan. (This generation will not pass away until all these things happen.)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 24:34, "Sólo entonces terminará esta era de maldad" (Only then will this era of wickedness end), presents a clear and accessible message for Spanish speakers, yet it does not accurately reflect the original Greek meaning, which emphasizes that 'this generation' will not pass away until all these events occur. The phrase 'era de maldad' (era of wickedness) suggests a broader interpretation that diverges from the specific context of Jesus' audience, potentially leading to misunderstandings regarding His intent and the eschatological context. A more faithful translation would be: "Esta generación no pasará hasta que todas estas cosas sucedan" (This generation will not pass away until all these things happen), which aligns with conservative interpretations and preserves the urgency and finality of Christ's words. Overall, while the translation achieves a modern tone, minor adjustments are necessary to ensure fidelity to the original text.

**MAT 18:32**: _(Grade 81.7)_

**Source**:
> τότε προσκαλεσάμενος αὐτὸν ὁ κύριος αὐτοῦ λέγει αὐτῷ· δοῦλε πονηρέ, πᾶσαν τὴν ὀφειλὴν ἐκείνην ἀφῆκά σοι, ἐπεὶ παρεκάλεσάς με.  
(Then his lord called him and said to him, 'O wicked servant! I forgave you all that debt because you begged me.')

**Translation**:
> El rey, sin pérdida de tiempo, mandó llamar al hombre al que había perdonado. “¡Malvado! ¡Perverso!”, le dijo. “¡Así que yo te perdoné aquella inmensa deuda porque me lo pediste,

**Suggested Translation**:

("The king, upon calling him, said: 'Negligent servant, I forgave you all that enormous debt because you sincerely asked me. Shouldn't you also have compassion on your fellow?"

The translation of Matthew 18:32 captures the core message effectively for a modern Spanish-speaking audience. However, the phrases "¡Malvado! ¡Perverso!" ("Wicked! Perverse!") may be perceived as overly harsh and informal, potentially detracting from the seriousness of the biblical lesson on mercy and forgiveness. The phrase "porque me lo pediste" ("because you begged me") could also be adjusted for formality and fluency, as it might dilute the original context of supplication. **MAT 23:5**: _(Grade 81.7)_

**Source**:
> πάντα δὲ τὰ ἔργα αὐτῶν ποιοῦσι πρὸς τὸ θεαθῆναι τοῖς ἀνθρώποις. πλατύνουσι γὰρ τὰ φυλακτήρια αὐτῶν καὶ μεγαλύνουσι τὰ κράσπεδα τῶν ἱματίων αὐτῶν,  
> ("But all their works they do to be seen by men. They make their phylacteries broad and enlarge the borders of their garments.")

**Translation**:
> »¡Y luego se dedican a hacer obras de caridad para que los demás los vean! Para aparentar santidad, se ponen en la frente y en los brazos porciones de las Escrituras escritas en las tiras de pergamino o piel más anchas que puedan encontrar, y procuran que los flecos de sus mantos sean más largos que los de los demás.  
> ("And then they dedicate themselves to doing charitable works so that others may see them! To appear holy, they wear on their foreheads and arms portions of the Scriptures written on the widest strips of parchment or leather they can find, and they try to make the fringes of their garments longer than those of others.")

**Suggested Translation**:
> »Todo lo que hacen, lo hacen para ser vistos por los demás. Ampliarán las cajas de las Escrituras que llevan en la frente y en los brazos, y alargarán los flecos de sus mantos, buscando la aprobación de la gente.  
> ("Everything they do, they do to be seen by others. They will enlarge the boxes of Scriptures they wear on their foreheads and arms, and they will lengthen the fringes of their garments, seeking the approval of people.")

**Combined Review**:
Summary:
The translation of MAT 23:5 has received mixed feedback from reviewers. While it captures the essence of Jesus' rebuke toward the Pharisees and presents the content in a clear and engaging manner, several reviewers expressed concerns regarding its accuracy and theological fidelity. The phrase "obras de caridad" (charitable works) does not fully encapsulate the broader meaning of "έργα" (works) in the original Greek, which includes all deeds rather than being limited to charity. Additionally, phrases like "aparentar santidad" (to appear holy) may undermine the seriousness of the original text. It is recommended to use terminology such as "buenas obras" (good works) or "actos de justicia" (acts of justice) to better reflect the original intent. Reviewers also noted that terms like "porciones de las Escrituras" (portions of the Scriptures) could be clarified to specify "escrituras en tiras de pergamino" (scriptures on strips of parchment) for better accuracy. While the modern tone is appreciated for accessibility, achieving a balance between contemporary language and the reverence due to scripture remains crucial. Refining certain phrases and ensuring clarity could significantly enhance the translation's effectiveness.

However, the inclusion of 'Gracias' (Thank you) at the end detracts from the solemnity and authority expected in a biblical context. A more fitting conclusion would emphasize acknowledgment and reverence, such as 'Sí, Señor.' (Yes, Lord.) Overall, while the translation captures the core meaning and is engaging, adjustments are recommended to ensure it aligns more closely with the traditional biblical tone.

**MAT 15:15**: _(Grade 83.3)_

**Source**:
> ἀποκριθεὶς δὲ ὁ Πέτρος εἶπεν αὐτῷ· φράσον ἡμῖν τὴν παραβολὴν ταύτην. (And Peter answered him, "Explain this parable to us.")

**Translation**:
> Pedro le pidió que les explicara aquello de que comer los alimentos que la ley judía prohíbe no es lo que contamina al hombre. (Peter asked him to explain to them that eating foods that the Jewish law prohibits is not what defiles a person.)

**Suggested Translation**:

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 15:15 has garnered mixed feedback, highlighting both its strengths and areas for improvement. Many reviewers commend the translation for its clarity and accessibility to modern Spanish speakers, noting that it effectively captures the essence of Peter's inquiry. However, there is a consensus that the translation might be overly focused on dietary laws, which detracts from the deeper spiritual implications of Jesus' message regarding inner purity versus external traditions.

Several reviewers point out that the phrase "no es lo que contamina al hombre" (is not what defiles a person) could lead to misunderstanding, as it suggests a focus on dietary restrictions rather than reflecting Peter's request for clarification about a parable. A more faithful rendering of the source text is recommended to better align with the original inquiry.

In conclusion, while the translation serves its purpose of being relatable and modern, refining certain phrases could enhance its theological accuracy and ensure that it reflects the true intent of the passage.

**MAT 22:5**: _(Grade 83.3)_

**Source**:
> οἱ δὲ ἀμελήσαντες ἀπῆλθον, ὁ μὲν εἰς τὸν ἴδιον ἀγρόν, ὁ δὲ εἰς τὴν ἐμπορίαν αὐτοῦ; (But they paid no attention and went away, one to his own farm, another to his business.)

**Translation**:
> Algunos de los invitados se rieron de los mensajeros y se fueron a sus labranzas o negocios; (Some of the guests laughed at the messengers and went to their fields or businesses.)

**Suggested Translation**:
> Algunos de los invitados despreciaron la invitación y se fueron a trabajar en sus campos o a sus negocios; (Some of the guests despised the invitation and went to work in their fields or to their businesses.)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 22:5 generally conveys the original text's essence but requires refinement in clarity and style. The phrase "se rieron de los mensajeros" (they laughed at the messengers) does not fully capture the dismissive attitude present in the Greek, as it implies mockery rather than disregard; terms like "despreciaron" (despised) would communicate a stronger sense of disdain. Furthermore, while "se fueron a sus labranzas o negocios" (they went to their fields or businesses) is clear, a phrasing such as "se fueron a trabajar en sus campos o a sus negocios" (they went to work in their fields or to their businesses) might enhance understanding. Adjustments for clarity and tone are essential, especially considering the message's gravity regarding the invitation to the Kingdom of God. The use of "labranza" (farming) may also be confusing; more accessible terms like "trabajos" (jobs) or "actividades" (activities) might resonate better with the audience. Overall, this translation is a good effort but can be improved to better reflect the seriousness and nuances of the biblical message.

> ποιήσατε οὖν καρπὸν ἄξιον τῆς μετανοίας, (Therefore produce fruit worthy of repentance)

**Translation**:

The translation of Matthew 3:8, "Demuestren, antes de bautizarse, que están arrepentidos," (Show that you are repentant before being baptized) effectively communicates the core message of repentance. However, several reviews point out that the phrase "antes de bautizarse" (before being baptized) adds unnecessary context that is not explicitly stated in the original Greek, which emphasizes producing fruit as evidence of repentance. A more direct translation, such as "Produzcan, pues, frutos dignos de arrepentimiento," (Therefore, produce fruits worthy of repentance) captures the essence and urgency of John's call for repentance more accurately.

Additionally, while the current translation is engaging for modern Spanish speakers, it could be improved for clarity in terms of theological implications and fidelity to the original text. The overall sentiment across reviews suggests maintaining the imperative call to action while ensuring that the translation reflects the original message's depth and intent.

**MAT 22:34**: _(Grade 85.0)_

**Source**:
> Οἱ δὲ Φαρισαῖοι ἀκούσαντες ὅτι ἐφίμωσε τοὺς Σαδδουκαίους, συνήχθησαν ἐπὶ τὸ αὐτό, (But the Pharisees, hearing that He had silenced the Sadducees, gathered together)

**Translation**:
> Los fariseos no se dejaron amedrentar por la derrota de los saduceos (The Pharisees were not intimidated by the defeat of the Sadducees)

**Suggested Translation**:
> Los fariseos, al oír que Jesús había silenciado a los saduceos, se reunieron entre sí. (The Pharisees, hearing that Jesus had silenced the Sadducees, gathered together)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 22:34 presents the original Greek text in a clear and accessible modern Spanish style. However, the phrase "no se dejaron amedrentar por la derrota de los saduceos" (they were not intimidated by the defeat of the Sadducees) may not accurately reflect the original text's intent. The reviews collectively suggest that the focus should be more on the Pharisees gathering in response to Jesus' silencing of the Sadducees, rather than implying a reaction of intimidation. A more neutral wording, such as "Los fariseos, al oír que Jesús había silenciado a los saduceos, se reunieron entre sí," (The Pharisees, hearing that Jesus had silenced the Sadducees, gathered together) is recommended to better convey the sense of the passage. Additionally, a slightly more formal and reverent tone would align better with biblical translation standards, considering the seriousness of the context.

**MAT 23:32**: _(Grade 85.0)_

**Source**:
> καὶ ὑμεῖς πληρώσατε τὸ μέτρον τῶν πατέρων ὑμῶν. (And you are filling the measure of your fathers.)

**Translation**:
> ¡Acaben de imitarlos! ¡Pónganse a la altura de ellos! (Finish imitating them! Live up to them!)

**Suggested Translation**:
> Y ustedes también están llenando la medida de sus padres. (And you are also filling the measure of your fathers.)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 23:32, "¡Acaben de imitarlos! ¡Pónganse a la altura de ellos!" (Finish imitating them! Live up to them!) successfully captures the essence of the original Greek text while maintaining accessibility for modern Spanish-speaking audiences. However, the phrase "¡Acaben de imitarlos!" (Finish imitating them!) could be interpreted as a call to simply mimic the actions of the fathers rather than conveying the original intent of judgment against their sins. Some reviewers suggested that alternatives like "¡Completen la medida de sus padres!" (Complete the measure of your fathers!) might better express the condemnation intended in the original. Despite some critiques regarding clarity and fidelity to the source material, the translation generally reflects the tone and urgency of Jesus' message effectively. Overall, while engaging for a contemporary audience, minor adjustments could enhance the accuracy and convey the intended gravity of the rebuke.

**MAT 24:8**: _(Grade 85.0)_

> πάντα δὲ ταῦτα ἀρχὴ ὠδίνων. (But all these things are the beginning of birth pains.)  

**Translation**:

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 24:8, rendered as "Pero esto será sólo el principio de los horrores que vendrán" (But this will be only the beginning of the horrors that will come), captures the urgency of the original message, though the term "horrores" (horrors) might not fully align with the original Greek's implication of suffering or "birth pains" (ὠδίνων). A consensus suggests that using terms like "dolores" (pains) or "tribulaciones" (tribulations) would provide a more precise theological understanding, consistent with traditional interpretations. This would enhance the clarity and accuracy for conservative readers who seek a direct connection to the scriptural language. While the current translation is generally effective and engaging for a Latin American audience, slight adjustments could further improve fidelity to the source material and deepen the theological significance. Overall, the translation is rated positively but acknowledges that minor refinements could enhance its precision.

**MAT 24:10**: _(Grade 85.0)_

**Source**:
> καὶ τότε σκανδαλισθήσονται πολλοὶ καὶ ἀλλήλους παραδώσουσι καὶ μισήσουσιν ἀλλήλους. (And then many will be offended and will betray one another and will hate one another.)

**Translation**:
> y muchos de ustedes volverán a caer en pecado y traicionarán y aborrecerán a los demás. (and many of you will fall back into sin and betray and hate one another.)

**Suggested Translation**:
> y muchos se escandalizarán, y se traicionarán y se odiarán unos a otros. (and many will be offended, and will betray one another and will hate one another.)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 24:10 is generally considered effective and conveys the original meaning well. However, there are notable concerns regarding the phrase 'volverán a caer en pecado' (will fall back into sin), which may lead to misunderstandings. This phrase could be interpreted as less direct than the original Greek term 'σκανδαλισθήσονται' (will be offended or scandalized), which emphasizes a moral failing or stumbling rather than simply sinning again. Additionally, the expression 'aborrecerán a los demás' (will hate one another) could be softened to 'se odiarán mutuamente' (will hate each other), aligning more closely with the intent of mutual betrayal as found in the original text. Overall, while the translation serves the goal of accessibility, it requires slight refinements for clarity and precision in order to reflect the serious warnings presented in Jesus' message.

**MAT 25:24-25**: _(Grade 85.0)_

**Source**:
> προσελθὼν δὲ καὶ ὁ τὸ ἓν τάλαντον εἰληφὼς εἶπε· κύριε· ἔγνων σε ὅτι σκληρὸς εἶ ἄνθρωπος, θερίζων ὅπου οὐκ ἔσπειρας καὶ συνάγων ὅθεν οὐ διεσκόρπισας·
> καὶ φοβηθεὶς ἀπελθὼν ἔκρυψα τὸ τάλαντόν σου ἐν τῇ γῇ· ἴδε ἔχεις τὸ σόν.  
(When he had received the one talent, he came and said, 'Lord, I knew you to be a hard man, reaping where you did not sow, and gathering where you scattered no seed; and I was afraid, and went and hid your talent in the ground. Here you have what is yours.)

**Translation**:
> »Cuando el que había recibido los diez mil pesos se presentó ante el jefe, le dijo: “Señor, como sabía que eres tan duro que te quedarías con cualquier utilidad que yo obtuviera, escondí el dinero. Aquí tienes hasta el último centavo que me diste”.  
(When the one who had received the ten thousand pesos came to his master, he said: 'Lord, since I knew you were so hard that you would keep any profit I could make, I hid the money. Here is every last cent you gave me.')

**Suggested Translation**:
> »Cuando el que había recibido los diez mil pesos se presentó ante el jefe, le dijo: “Señor, sabía que eres un hombre exigente, que cosechas donde no has sembrado y recoges donde no has esparcido. Por eso, atemorizado, fui y escondí tu dinero en la tierra. Aquí está lo que te pertenece.”  
(When the one who had received the ten thousand pesos came to his master, he said: 'Lord, I knew you to be a demanding man, reaping where you have not sown and gathering where you have not scattered. Therefore, afraid, I went and hid your money in the ground. Here is what belongs to you.')

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 25:24-25 effectively conveys the original message and intent of the scripture, maintaining a clear and accessible modern Spanish style suitable for Latin American audiences. However, the use of the phrase "tan duro" (so hard) could potentially misrepresent the master's character as more informal and less reverent than intended, while also softening the stronger implications of 'harsh' from the Greek text. The colloquial expression "hasta el último centavo" (every last cent) could detract from the seriousness of the servant's actions, suggesting a trivialization of the context. Overall, the translation is solid, preserving the essence of the parable, yet there are areas for improvement, particularly in using language that reflects the gravity and theological depth expected in a conservative biblical context.

**MAT 17:25**: _(Grade 85.3)_

**Source**:  
> λέγει, ναί. καὶ ὅτε εἰσῆλθεν εἰς τὴν οἰκίαν, προέφθασεν αὐτὸν ὁ Ἰησοῦς λέγων· τί σοι δοκεῖ, Σίμων; οἱ βασιλεῖς τῆς γῆς ἀπὸ τίνων λαμβάνουσι τέλη ἢ κῆνσον; ἀπὸ τῶν υἱῶν αὐτῶν ἢ ἀπὸ τῶν ἀλλοτρίων;  
(He says, "Yes." And when he entered the house, Jesus anticipated him, saying, "What do you think, Simon? From whom do the kings of the earth take customs or taxes? From their own sons or from strangers?")  

**Translation**:  
> —¡Claro que los paga! —les respondió Pedro—, e inmediatamente entró a la casa a hablarle a Jesús sobre el asunto.  
(No doubt they pay —Peter replied—, and he immediately entered the house to speak to Jesus about the matter.)  
> No había pronunciado todavía la primera palabra, cuando Jesús le preguntó: —  
(He had not yet spoken the first word, when Jesus asked him:)  
> ¿A quién crees tú, Pedro, que cobran tributos los reyes de la tierra? ¿A sus súbditos o a los extranjeros?  
(To whom do you think, Peter, that the kings of the earth collect tribute? From their subjects or from strangers?)  

**Suggested Translation**:  
> —Sí, sí paga —respondió Pedro—. Y cuando entró en la casa, Jesús le habló primero, diciendo: —¿Qué piensas, Simón? ¿De quiénes cobran impuestos los reyes de la tierra? ¿De sus hijos o de los extranjeros?  
(—Yes, they pay —Peter replied—. And when he entered the house, Jesus spoke first to him, saying: —What do you think, Simon? From whom do the kings of the earth collect taxes? From their children or from foreigners?)  

**Combined Review**:
The translation of Matthew 17:25 is generally well-received, achieving clarity and modernity in language while maintaining the essence of the original text. Most reviewers highlight the accessibility for Spanish speakers, particularly in Latin America, and commend the conversational tone captured in the phrase "¡Claro que los paga!" ("No doubt they pay!") However, some reviewers note that this informal expression may be too casual for a sacred text. They suggest finding a balance between approachability and reverence. While the interaction between Peter and Jesus is effectively rendered, slight adjustments are recommended for a more formal tone, ensuring that the theological weight of the passage is preserved. A more direct representation of the original dialogue without extra embellishments is encouraged to enhance fidelity to the source. Overall, the translation demonstrates a solid effort towards making the scripture engaging and understandable, although attention to formal language could improve its appropriateness for a biblical context.

**MAT 4:6**: _(Grade 85.5)_

> καὶ λέγει αὐτῷ· εἰ υἱὸς εἶ τοῦ Θεοῦ, βάλε σεαυτὸν κάτω· γέγραπται γὰρ ὅτι τοῖς ἀγγέλοις αὐτοῦ ἐντελεῖται περὶ σοῦ, καὶ ἐπὶ χειρῶν ἀροῦσί σε, μήποτε προσκόψῃς πρὸς λίθον τὸν πόδα σου. (And he said to him, "If you are the Son of God, throw yourself down; for it is written, 'He will command his angels concerning you,' and 'On their hands they will bear you up, lest you strike your foot against a stone.'")

**Translation**:
> —Si eres el Hijo de Dios —le dijo—, tírate desde aquí. Las Escrituras dicen que Dios enviará a sus ángeles a cuidarte, y ni siquiera te tropezarás con las rocas. ("If you are the Son of God," he said, "throw yourself down from here. For it is written, 'He will command his angels to guard you, and they will lift you up in their hands, so that you will not strike your foot against a stone.'")

**Suggested Translation**:
> —Si eres el Hijo de Dios —le dijo—, lánzate desde aquí, porque las Escrituras dicen que Dios enviará a sus ángeles a cuidarte, y ellos te sostendrán en sus manos para que no tropieces con piedra alguna. ("If you are the Son of God," he said, "throw yourself down, for it is written: 'He will command his angels concerning you, and they will lift you up in their hands, so that you will not strike your foot against a stone.'")

There is consensus that the phrase 'tírate desde aquí' should be replaced with 'lánzate desde aquí' for a more dynamic and engaging tone. Several reviewers noted that the translation should retain a level of reverence and authority appropriate for a conservative Christian audience, particularly concerning scriptural references. While the core message and theological implications are generally well-preserved, adjustments are recommended to maintain a formal tone and enhance clarity. The phrase 'y ni siquiera te tropezarás con las rocas' has been flagged as colloquial; a more traditional rendering could be beneficial. Overall, the translation reflects a good effort toward clarity and fidelity to the original scripture, with some room for improvement in tone and precision.

**MAT 10:11**: _(Grade 85.5)_

**Source**:
> εἰς ἣν δ᾽ ἂν πόλιν ἢ κώμην εἰσέλθητε, ἐξετάσατε τίς ἐν αὐτῇ ἄξιός ἐστι, κἀκεῖ μείνατε ἕως ἂν ἐξέλθητε.  
(Translation: "And into whatever city or village you enter, inquire who in it is worthy, and stay there until you go out.")

**Translation**:
> Cuando lleguen a cualquier ciudad o pueblo, busquen a una persona de confianza y quédense en su casa hasta que se vayan a otro pueblo.  
(Translation: "When you enter any city or village, look for a trustworthy person and stay in their house until you leave for another village.")

**Suggested Translation**:
> Cuando lleguen a cualquier ciudad o pueblo, busquen a una persona digna y permanezcan en su casa hasta que salgan.  
(Translation: "When you arrive at any city or town, look for a worthy person and stay in their house until you leave.")

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 10:11 is generally well-executed, achieving clarity and accessibility for modern Spanish speakers. While the phrase "busquen a una persona de confianza" ("look for a trustworthy person") effectively conveys trustworthiness, it does not fully capture the nuance of "quién es digno" ("who is worthy") from the original text, which implies finding someone who is worthy. A preferred phrase could be "busquen a una persona digna" ("look for a worthy person") to maintain theological fidelity. Furthermore, simplifying "hasta que se vayan a otro pueblo" ("until they go to another village") to "hasta que salgan" ("until you leave") enhances conciseness. The instruction about staying in one house until leaving is clear and aligns with the original intent of the scripture. Overall, this is a commendable translation that deserves a solid score while recognizing minor adjustments could improve accuracy and better reflect the original meaning.

> τότε ἔρχεται πρὸς τοὺς μαθητὰς αὐτοῦ καὶ λέγει αὐτοῖς· καθεύδετε τὸ λοιπὸν καὶ ἀναπαύεσθε! ἰδοὺ ἤγγικεν ἡ ὥρα καὶ ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου παραδίδοται εἰς χεῖρας ἁμαρτωλῶν. **Translation**:
> Cuando volvió a los discípulos les dijo:  
> «Duerman, descansen…, pero no, ha llegado la hora. Me van a entregar en manos de los pecadores. (When he returned to his disciples, he said to them, 'Sleep, rest… but no, the hour has come. They will hand me over to sinners.')

> «Ahora pueden descansar, pero ha llegado la hora. Me entregan en manos de los impíos.» ("Now you can rest, but the hour has come. They are handing me over to the wicked.")

Overall, the translation is a commendable effort but could benefit from minor refinements.

Suggestions include using "cuando los judíos celebraban la Pascua" (when the Jews celebrated Passover) or simply stating the event during the Feast of Unleavened Bread.  
- Consider rephrasing "cena de Pascua" (Passover dinner) to "celebración de la Pascua" (celebration of Passover) or just "Pascua" (Passover) to better align with contemporary Christian terminology and maintain a reverent tone suitable for biblical text.  
Overall, the translation meets the goal of making the Bible more accessible, but minor adjustments in phrasing would enhance engagement and clarity for the target audience.

> ¿No sabes que podría pedirle a mi Padre que me enviara doce mil ángeles y me los enviaría al instante? (Do you not know that I could ask my Father to send me twelve thousand angels, and He would send them immediately?)

**Combined Review**:
_(Average Grade: 86.3)_: The translation of MAT 26:53 effectively captures the essence of the original Greek text while making it accessible to a modern Spanish-speaking audience. The phrase, "¿No sabes que podría pedirle a mi Padre que me enviara doce mil ángeles y me los enviaría al instante?" (Do you not know that I could ask my Father to send me twelve thousand angels, and He would send them immediately?) conveys both the power of Jesus and the urgency of His situation. However, there is a consensus that the translation should retain the term "doce legiones" (twelve legions) instead of "doce mil ángeles" (twelve thousand angels) to preserve the theological significance and gravity of the message. The original term connects with Roman military context, suggesting authority and divine power. While the modern language choice is appropriate, emphasizing this aspect of authority is crucial from a conservative Christian perspective. Overall, it is a solid translation that meets the objective, with a recommendation for minor adjustments to enhance theological fidelity.

> »Los ojos son la lámpara del cuerpo. Si tu ojo es bondadoso, andarás en la luz; (The eyes are the lamp of the body. If your eye is good, you will walk in the light;)  

**Combined Review**:
The translation of Matthew 6:22 is generally accurate and conveys the original meaning effectively, particularly in its modern presentation for Spanish-speaking audiences. However, there are suggestions for improving clarity and theological depth. The phrase "Si tu ojo es bondadoso, andarás en la luz" (If your eye is good, you will walk in the light) can be enhanced; using "vivirás en la luz" (you will live in the light) or considering "ojo sano" (healthy eye) instead of "bondadoso" (good) might resonate more clearly with audiences, emphasizing the spiritual implications of clarity and generosity. While the translation captures the essence of the scripture well, these adjustments could deepen understanding and connection with the text. Overall, it successfully fulfills the goals of accessibility and engagement.

**MAT 7:4**: _(Grade 87.2)_

(Translation: Or how will you say to your brother, "Let me take the speck out of your eye," when there is a log in your own eye?)  

**Translation**:

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 7:4 is effective in conveying the metaphor and core message of self-examination before judging others. It utilizes modern and accessible language, making it relatable for Spanish speakers in Latin America. However, several reviews noted that the choice of 'amigo' (friend) could be revised to 'hermano' (brother) to reflect the original Greek term 'ἀδελφῷ' (brother), which emphasizes community and familial relationships. Additionally, while the metaphor is clear, phrases like 'la viga que tienes en el tuyo no te deja ver' (the beam in your eye prevents you from seeing) could benefit from further refinement for greater clarity and resonance with a conservative audience. Overall, the translation is strong but would improve with these minor adjustments for clarity and cultural relevance.

**MAT 7:9**: _(Grade 87.3)_

> ἢ τίς ἐστιν ἐξ ὑμῶν ἄνθρωπος, ὃν ἐὰν αἰτήσῃ ὁ υἱὸς αὐτοῦ ἄρτον, μὴ λίθον ἐπιδώσει αὐτῷ; (Or what man is there among you, who, if his son asks for bread, will give him a stone?)

**Translation**:
> ¿Si su hijo le pide pan, ¿quién de ustedes será capaz de darle una piedra? (If his son asks for bread, who of you will be able to give him a stone?)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 7:9 is commendable, effectively conveying the essence of the original Greek text while maintaining clarity for a modern Spanish-speaking audience. While it aligns with the objective of accessibility and engagement, there are suggestions to improve phrasing. The phrase '¿quién de ustedes será capaz de darle una piedra?' could be reworded to '¿quién de ustedes le dará una piedra?' (who of you will give him a stone?) to enhance clarity and readability. This adjustment retains the rhetorical impact and reflects the original text's simplicity, aligning well with the conservative Christian perspective that emphasizes God’s goodness and loving nature. Overall, with these minor adjustments, the translation achieves its goal of being both faithful and accessible.

**MAT 7:13**: _(Grade 87.3)_

**Source**:
> Εἰσέλθετε διὰ τῆς στενῆς πύλης· ὅτι πλατεῖα ἡ πύλη καὶ εὐρύχωρος ἡ ὁδὸς ἡ ἀπάγουσα εἰς τὴν ἀπώλειαν, καὶ πολλοί εἰσιν οἱ εἰσερχόμενοι δι᾽ αὐτῆς. (Enter through the narrow gate; for wide is the gate and broad is the way that leads to destruction, and many are those who enter through it.)

**Translation**:
> »Entren por la puerta estrecha, porque ancha es la puerta y espacioso el camino que conducen a la perdición; por eso muchísimas personas los prefieren. ("Enter through the narrow gate, for wide is the gate and broad is the way that leads to destruction; therefore, many people prefer it.")

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 7:13 captures the essence of the original Greek text while presenting it in a clear, modern, and accessible Spanish suitable for Latin American audiences. Phrases like "puerta estrecha" (narrow gate) and "camino espacioso" (broad path) effectively communicate the contrast between the narrow way leading to life and the broad way leading to destruction. However, the phrase "por eso muchísimas personas los prefieren" (therefore many people prefer it) has been noted as slightly misleading; it implies preference rather than emphasizing the stark warning inherent in the text. Suggestions for improvement include rephrasing this part to clarify the reality of many choosing the broad path, with alternatives like "y son muchos los que eligen entrar por ella" (and many are those who choose to enter it) or similar constructions to reflect the original message accurately. Overall, the translation is strong, with a commendable effort and minor adjustments needed for clarity and fidelity to the scripture's warning.

**MAT 25:18**: _(Grade 87.3)_

> ὁ δὲ τὸ ἓν λαβὼν ἀπελθὼν ὤρυξεν ἐν τῇ γῇ καὶ ἀπέκρυψε τὸ ἀργύριον τοῦ κυρίου αὐτοῦ. (But the one who received the one talent went away and dug in the ground and hid his master's money.)

**Translation**:
> Pero el que recibió los diez mil, cavó en la tierra y escondió el dinero para que estuviera seguro. (But the one who received the ten thousand dug in the ground and hid the money to keep it safe.)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 25:18 is generally well-executed and conveys the essence of the original Greek text effectively. The phrase "cavó en la tierra y escondió el dinero para que estuviera seguro" (dug in the ground and hid the money to keep it safe) successfully communicates the action taken by the servant. However, there is a consensus that the phrase "para que estuviera seguro" (to keep it safe) may inadvertently suggest a positive motivation for the servant's actions, rather than the implied fear and lack of initiative present in the original text. Suggestions for refinement include rephrasing to emphasize the servant's reluctance or fear, such as using alternatives like "para asegurarlo" (to secure it) or "para protegerlo" (to protect it). Overall, while the translation is clear and accessible for contemporary Spanish speakers, minor adjustments could enhance its fidelity to the original intent, reinforcing the moral lessons of responsibility and stewardship within a conservative Christian framework.

**MAT 27:1**: _(Grade 87.3)_

**Source**:
> Πρωΐας δὲ γενομένης συμβούλιον ἔλαβον πάντες οἱ ἀρχιερεῖς καὶ οἱ πρεσβύτεροι τοῦ λαοῦ κατὰ τοῦ Ἰησοῦ ὥστε θανατῶσαι αὐτόν·  
(But when morning had come, all the chief priests and elders of the people took counsel against Jesus to put him to death.)

**Translation**:
> Al amanecer, los principales sacerdotes y funcionarios judíos se reunieron a deliberar sobre la mejor manera de lograr que el gobierno romano condenara a muerte a Jesús.  
(At dawn, the chief priests and Jewish officials gathered to deliberate on the best way to get the Roman government to condemn Jesus to death.)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 27:1 is generally clear and accurate, effectively conveying the original text's meaning in a modern and accessible Spanish style suitable for Latin American readers. It captures the seriousness of the context where religious leaders plot against Jesus. 

However, several reviews suggest improvements. The phrase "los principales sacerdotes y funcionarios judíos" could be more precisely translated as "los principales sacerdotes y los ancianos del pueblo" to align with the original Greek terms 'ἀρχιερεῖς' (chief priests) and 'πρεσβύτεροι' (elders). This adjustment would help preserve the text's original intent and authority. 

Additionally, the phrase "a deliberar sobre la mejor manera de lograr que el gobierno romano condenara a muerte a Jesús" could benefit from simplification and greater directness, emphasizing the council's actions rather than their methods. This is crucial as it reflects the gravity of the situation and aligns with the conservative Christian perspective, which emphasizes the themes of betrayal and injustice present in the passage. 

Overall, while the translation is commendable and accessible, slight adjustments could enhance its precision and impact, making it resonate more effectively with a conservative audience.

**MAT 15:32**: _(Grade 87.5)_

> Ὁ δὲ Ἰησοῦς προσκαλεσάμενος τοὺς μαθητὰς αὐτοῦ εἶπε· σπλαγχνίζομαι ἐπὶ τὸν ὄχλον, ὅτι ἤδη ἡμέραι τρεῖς προσμένουσί μοι καὶ οὐκ ἔχουσι τί φάγωσι· καὶ ἀπολῦσαι αὐτοὺς νήστεις οὐ θέλω, μήποτε ἐκλυθῶσιν ἐν τῇ ὁδῷ.

**MAT 26:61**: _(Grade 87.5)_

> εἶπον· οὗτος ἔφη, δύναμαι καταλῦσαι τὸν ναὸν τοῦ Θεοῦ καὶ διὰ τριῶν ἡμερῶν οἰκοδομῆσαι αὐτόν. (They said: 'This man said, I am able to destroy the temple of God and in three days rebuild it.')  

**Translation**:  
> declararon:  
> ―Este hombre dijo que era capaz de destruir el templo de Dios y reconstruirlo en tres días. (They declared: 'This man said that he was able to destroy the temple of God and rebuild it in three days.')  

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 26:61 is generally clear, accurate, and effectively captures the essence of the original text. The modern Spanish used makes the verse accessible to Latin American audiences. The phrase, "Este hombre dijo que era capaz de destruir el templo de Dios y reconstruirlo en tres días," successfully conveys the critical accusation against Jesus, which is vital for understanding this passage's context. However, several reviews suggest that the translation could benefit from adjustments to enhance theological depth and reverence, aligning more closely with conservative Christian interpretations. Specifically, the translation might incorporate more formal phrasing to emphasize the significance of Jesus' claims regarding the temple, enhancing both clarity and the overall seriousness of the statement. Overall, while the translation is commendable, slight stylistic and theological refinements are recommended for improved engagement and fidelity to traditional interpretations.

**MAT 10:16**: _(Grade 87.7)_

**Source**:
> Ἰδοὺ ἐγὼ ἀποστέλλω ὑμᾶς ὡς πρόβατα ἐν μέσῳ λύκων· γίνεσθε οὖν φρόνιμοι ὡς οἱ ὄφεις καὶ ἀκέραιοι ὡς αἱ περιστεραί.  
 ("Behold, I send you out as sheep in the midst of wolves; therefore be wise as serpents and harmless as doves.")

**Translation**:
> "Ustedes son como ovejas y los estoy enviando a meterse donde están los lobos. Sean prudentes como serpientes e inofensivos como palomas."  
 ("You are like sheep and I am sending you into the midst of wolves. Be wise as serpents and harmless as doves.")

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 10:16 effectively captures the essence of the original Greek text, presenting a clear and accessible message suitable for Spanish speakers, especially in Latin America. Reviewers appreciate the modern and familiar phrasing, which enhances relatability, particularly the use of 'ustedes' for inclusivity. However, several comments suggest improving the phrase 'a meterse donde están los lobos' ("into the midst of wolves") for a more formal rendering, such as 'en medio de lobos' ("in the midst of wolves"), to better align with the solemnity of the biblical context. Additionally, there is a call for refinement in interpreting 'inofensivos' ("harmless") for 'ἀκέραιοι' ("pure" or "integrity") to convey purity or integrity more accurately. Despite these areas for enhancement, the overall assessment recognizes the translation's accessibility, urgency, and the successful communication of wisdom and innocence, maintaining fidelity to the intended message of the scripture.

**MAT 10:25**: _(Grade 87.7)_

**Source**:
> ἀρκετὸν τῷ μαθητῇ ἵνα γένηται ὡς ὁ διδάσκαλος αὐτοῦ, καὶ τῷ δούλῳ ὡς ὁ κύριος αὐτοῦ. (It is enough for the disciple to be like his teacher, and the servant like his lord.) εἰ τὸν οἰκοδεσπότην Βεελζεβοὺλ ἐκάλεσαν, πόσῳ μᾶλλον τοὺς οἰκιακοὺς αὐτοῦ; (If they have called the master of the house Beelzebub, how much more those of his household?)  

**Translation**:
> Es suficiente para el discípulo ser como su maestro y para el siervo como su señor. (It is enough for the disciple to be like his teacher and the servant like his lord.) Y si a mí, que soy como el padre de familia, me llaman Beelzebú, ¿qué no les dirán a ustedes? (And if they have called me, who am like the head of the household, Beelzebub, what will they not say to you?)  

(Translation: "It is enough for the disciple to be like his teacher, and the servant like his lord. If they have called the master of the house Beelzebub, how much more those of his household?")  

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 10:25 effectively communicates the original meaning, using modern and accessible Spanish for Latin American audiences. The phrase "Es suficiente para el discípulo ser como su maestro" accurately captures the essence of the text, reflecting the relationship between disciple and teacher. However, the expression "soy como el padre de familia" might mislead readers regarding Jesus' authority; a more direct reference to His lordship would be beneficial. While the translation is generally clear and relatable, adjustments could enhance clarity, particularly in the final reference to Beelzebub, which should be contextualized to avoid confusion. Suggestions include using "más que" instead of "como" for added clarity. Overall, the translation serves its purpose but has room for improvement in precision and faithfulness to the text.

The translation of MAT 15:31 effectively conveys the emotional and miraculous elements of the passage, successfully engaging modern Spanish-speaking audiences. The phrases such as '¡Qué espectáculo!' (What a spectacle!) and 'maravillados' (amazed) evoke awe, reflecting the nature of the events. However, some reviewers noted that phrases like 'los miembros inútiles de los lisiados eran restaurados' (the useless limbs of the disabled were restored) might be seen as insensitive and suggested revisions for greater respect and dignity towards those described. Additionally, 'gentío' (crowd) could be interpreted negatively, with 'multitud' (multitude) being a preferable term. There is also concern that expressions may lack reverence from a conservative perspective. > ―Entonces, los suyos quedan exentos, ¿verdad?  
> —añadió Jesús—.

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 17:27 is commendable and effectively captures the essence of the original Greek text while employing modern, accessible Spanish suitable for Latin American audiences. The use of direct speech and clear phrasing makes the dialogue engaging. Additionally, refining the phrase "en la boca del primer pez que saques" ("in the mouth of the first fish that you catch") could enhance clarity and emphasize the miraculous nature of the event. While the translation is generally strong and aligns well with conservative Christian values, some minor adjustments in phrasing and word choice could improve its fidelity to the original text. Overall, it meets the objectives of accessibility and engagement for Spanish speakers, earning it a solid evaluation.

**MAT 5:44**: _(Grade 87.8)_

> Ἐγὼ δὲ λέγω ὑμῖν, ἀγαπᾶτε τοὺς ἐχθροὺς ὑμῶν, εὐλογεῖτε τοὺς καταρωμένους ὑμᾶς, καλῶς ποιεῖτε τοῖς μισοῦσιν ὑμᾶς καὶ προσεύχεσθε ὑπὲρ τῶν ἐπηρεαζόντων ὑμᾶς καὶ διωκόντων ὑμᾶς,  
(But I say to you, Love your enemies, bless those who curse you, do good to those who hate you, and pray for those who spitefully use you and persecute you.)  

**Translation**:  
> Pero yo les digo: ¡Amen a sus enemigos! ¡Oren por quienes los persiguen!  
(But I say to you: Love your enemies! Pray for those who persecute you!)  

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 5:44 is generally clear and accessible, capturing the essence of Jesus' teaching about loving one's enemies and praying for persecutors. While the phrase "¡Amen a sus enemigos!" effectively communicates the command, it may cause confusion due to its inaccuracy; a more appropriate rendering would be "¡Amen a vuestros enemigos!" or simply "¡Aman a sus enemigos!" Additionally, there are suggestions to consider alternatives such as "¡Amen a sus adversarios!" to better convey the nuance of 'enemy' in a biblical context. The phrase "¡Oren por quienes los persiguen!" is correctly interpreted and aligns with the seriousness of the message. Although there are minor adjustments suggested regarding verb choice and phrasing, the overall translation is deemed effective and engaging for Spanish speakers, fulfilling the intent of the original text.

**MAT 6:25**: _(Grade 87.8)_

**Source**:
> Διὰ τοῦτο λέγω ὑμῖν, μὴ μεριμνᾶτε τῇ ψυχῇ ὑμῶν τί φάγητε καὶ τί πίητε, μηδὲ τῷ σώματι ὑμῶν τί ἐνδύσησθε· οὐχὶ ἡ ψυχὴ πλεῖόν ἐστι τῆς τροφῆς καὶ τὸ σῶμα τοῦ ἐνδύματος; (For this reason I say to you, do not worry about your soul, what you will eat and what you will drink, nor about your body, what you will wear. Is not the soul more than food and the body more than clothing?)  

**Translation**:
> »Por ello les aconsejo que no se preocupen por la comida, la bebida o la ropa. ¡Es mucho más importante tener vida y un cuerpo, que tener qué comer y qué vestir! (Therefore I advise you not to worry about food, drink, or clothing. It is much more important to have life and a body than to have something to eat and wear!)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 6:25 effectively captures the essence of the original text and is presented in a clear and accessible manner suitable for Spanish speakers in a Latin American context. The phrase "no se preocupen por la comida, la bebida o la ropa" (do not worry about food, drink, or clothing) accurately conveys the original message, emphasizing the importance of spiritual life over material concerns. However, the concluding phrase "¡Es mucho más importante tener vida y un cuerpo, que tener qué comer y qué vestir!" (It is much more important to have life and a body than to have something to eat and wear!) may come off as slightly informal and shifts the focus from the biblical intent, which emphasizes the relationship between spiritual and physical needs. A more direct translation such as "¿No es la vida más que el alimento y el cuerpo más que la vestimenta?" (Is not life more than food and the body more than clothing?) might be preferable to retain the gravity of the original message for a conservative audience. Overall, the translation is strong and adheres to the goal of engaging Spanish speakers while allowing for minor adjustments to enhance theological depth and fidelity to the source material.

**MAT 13:23**: _(Grade 88.0)_

However, there is a consensus that the term "maestros religiosos" (religious teachers) could be adjusted to a more traditional term like "escribas" (scribes) to resonate better with a conservative Christian audience. While the dialogue format adds engagement, some felt it strayed slightly from the original text's formal tone. Overall, the translation is strong, meeting the objectives of clarity and accessibility, though minor adjustments for formality and traditional wording could enhance it further.

(Well, there was once a family of seven brothers. The first married and died without having children, so the widow married the second brother. That brother also died without having children, and the wife married the next brother. This repeated until the woman was the wife of all seven brothers.)  

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 22:25-26 is generally well-executed, maintaining clarity and accessibility for Spanish speakers in Latin America, achieving a good balance between fidelity to the original Greek text and readability. However, some suggestions for improvement were made:

- The translation should emphasize the role of the brothers in the marriage customs, reflecting the cultural context more accurately rather than implying the widow's initiative.  
- The expression "la señora fue esposa de los siete hermanos" could be modified to "la mujer fue esposa de los siete" for improved clarity.

Overall, the translation is a commendable effort, with only minor adjustments needed for better precision and naturalness.

(And seeing a fig tree by the way, he came to it, and found nothing thereon, but leaves only, and said unto it, Let no fruit grow on thee henceforward for ever. And presently the fig tree withered away.)

**Translation**:
> Se acercó a una higuera del camino con la esperanza de encontrar en ella higos, ¡pero sólo encontró hojas! (He approached a fig tree by the road hoping to find figs on it, but found only leaves!)  
> ―¡Nunca jamás produzcas fruto! (Never shall you produce fruit!)  
> —le dijo. (he said to it.)  
> Y la higuera se secó. (And the fig tree withered.)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 21:19 is generally clear and utilizes modern Spanish effectively, making it relatable to a contemporary audience. It successfully captures the essential message of the original Greek text, particularly the significance of the fig tree's failure to produce fruit and the seriousness of Jesus's statement. The phrase '¡Nunca jamás produzcas fruto!' conveys urgency but could be improved with a more formal expression, such as 'Nunca más produzcas fruto,' for greater fluidity and a tone that reflects the seriousness of the context. Overall, the translation effectively communicates the biblical message while maintaining accessibility for Spanish speakers in Latin America, though minor adjustments could enhance its literary quality.

**MAT 21:33**: _(Grade 88.5)_

> Ἄλλην παραβολὴν ἀκούσατε. ἄνθρωπός τις ἦν οἰκοδεσπότης, ὅστις ἐφύτευσεν ἀμπελῶνα καὶ φραγμὸν αὐτῷ περιέθηκε καὶ ὤρυξεν ἐν αὐτῷ ληνὸν καὶ ᾠκοδόμησε πύργον, καὶ ἐξέδοτο αὐτὸν γεωργοῖς καὶ ἀπεδήμησεν.  
(Another parable you will hear. There was a certain man, a householder, who planted a vineyard and put a fence around it and dug a winepress in it and built a tower, and he leased it to farmers and went away.)  

**Translation**:
> Entonces les contó la siguiente parábola:  
> «Cierto hombre plantó una viña, la cercó, construyó una torre de vigilancia, y la arrendó a varios labradores. Según el contrato, estos habrían de compartir con el dueño el producto de la viña. El dueño se fue a otra región.  
(Then he told them the following parable: "A certain man planted a vineyard, fenced it, built a watchtower, and leased it to several tenants. According to the contract, they were to share the product of the vineyard with the owner. The owner went to another region.")  

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 21:33 effectively communicates the meaning of the original Greek text while maintaining accessibility for Spanish speakers in Latin America. The translation preserves the essence and theological implications of the original, making it relatable and understandable for the target audience. Some suggestions for improvement include:
- Consider changing "cercó" to "rodeó" for more natural phrasing.
- The phrase "la arrendó a varios labradores" could imply multiple tenants, which might not accurately reflect the singular "georgois" from the original text. Using "unos labradores" might suggest a more personal connection.
- Phrases could be more idiomatic, such as replacing "los labradores" with "los campesinos" for better resonance with Latin American readers.
- Overall fluidity could be improved, particularly in the sentence about the vineyard's features.  

In summary, the translation is strong and adheres to a conservative Christian viewpoint, but slight adjustments could enhance its clarity and relatability.

Additionally, the term "caudillo" may not be widely understood and could be replaced with simpler terms like "líder" or "guía" to enhance clarity across various Spanish-speaking contexts.  Overall, the translation is commendable for its clarity and faithfulness to the original, though slight adjustments in phrasing could strengthen its theological and literary impact.

**MAT 10:8**: _(Grade 89.0)_

> ἀσθενοῦντας θεραπεύετε, λεπροὺς καθαρίζετε, [νεκροὺς ἐγείρετε,] δαιμόνια ἐκβάλλετε· δωρεὰν ἐλάβετε, δωρεὰν δότε.  
(Heal the sick, cleanse the lepers, raise the dead, cast out demons; freely you have received, freely give.)

**Translation**:
> »Curen enfermos, resuciten muertos, sanen leprosos y echen fuera demonios. De la misma manera que ustedes están recibiendo este poder gratuitamente, tampoco cobren por sus servicios.  
(Heal the sick, raise the dead, cleanse the lepers, and cast out demons. Just as you have received this power freely, do not charge for your services.)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 10:8 is generally clear and well-executed, capturing the essence of the original Greek text. It effectively communicates the message using accessible language that resonates with a Latin American audience. The phrase regarding receiving power freely and not charging for services adds clarity to the principle of grace; however, it introduces nuances not explicitly found in the Greek text. Some reviewers noted that the phrase 'resuciten muertos' (raise the dead) may come off as casual or misinterpreted and suggested alternatives like 'devuelvan la vida a los muertos' (bring life back to the dead) to maintain gravity. Additionally, while the informal term 'cobren' (charge) is seen as potentially problematic, alternatives such as 'no pidan pago' (do not ask for payment) were recommended. Overall, the translation is effective and maintains theological integrity, but minor adjustments for clarity, tone, and punctuation could enhance its accuracy and reverence.

**MAT 11:28**: _(Grade 89.0)_

**Source**:
> Δεῦτε πρός με πάντες οἱ κοπιῶντες καὶ πεφορτισμένοι, κἀγὼ ἀναπαύσω ὑμᾶς. (Come to me, all who labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.)

**Translation**:

**Combined Review**:
The translation of Matthew 11:28 is clear and effectively captures the essence of the original Greek text. The choice of words such as 'cansados' (weary) and 'afligidos' (burdened) conveys Jesus' invitation to those who are struggling, making it relatable to modern Spanish speakers. However, some reviewers suggested that the term 'afligidos' (burdened) might be better replaced with 'agobiados' (overwhelmed) or 'cargados' (laden) to more accurately reflect the Greek 'πεφορτισμένοι' (heavy laden). The structure is generally engaging and accessible, though a more explicit connection to the concept of spiritual rest could enhance its impact. Overall, the translation is strong but could benefit from slight refinements in phrasing to improve clarity and depth.

**MAT 15:23**: _(Grade 89.0)_

> ὁ δὲ οὐκ ἀπεκρίθη αὐτῇ λόγον. καὶ προσελθόντες οἱ μαθηταὶ αὐτοῦ ἠρώτων αὐτὸν λέγοντες· ἀπόλυσον αὐτήν, ὅτι κράζει ὄπισθεν ἡμῶν.  (But he answered her not a word. And his disciples came and besought him, saying, Send her away; for she crieth after us.)

> ―Dile que se vaya, que ya nos tiene cansados. (Tell her to go away, for she troubles us.)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 15:23 successfully conveys the original Greek text's meaning while utilizing modern, accessible Spanish suitable for Latin American audiences. The phrase "Jesús no le respondió ni una sola palabra" captures Jesus' silence effectively, emphasizing this critical narrative aspect. However, the disciples' line, "que ya nos tiene cansados," while relatable, may come off as too colloquial and could potentially diminish the seriousness of the situation. Suggested alternatives such as "nos está cansando" would maintain clarity while better reflecting the gravity of their frustration. Despite minor adjustments that could enhance emotional depth and formality, the overall translation meets its objectives well, being clear, engaging, and true to the source material.

**MAT 3:14**: _(Grade 89.2)_

**MAT 5:22**: _(Grade 89.2)_

**Source**:
> Ἐγὼ δὲ λέγω ὑμῖν ὅτι πᾶς ὁ ὀργιζόμενος τῷ ἀδελφῷ αὐτοῦ εἰκῆ ἔνοχος ἔσται τῇ κρίσει· ὃς δ᾽ ἂν εἴπῃ τῷ ἀδελφῷ αὐτοῦ ῥακά, ἔνοχος ἔσται τῷ συνεδρίῳ· ὃς δ᾽ ἂν εἴπῃ μωρέ, ἔνοχος ἔσται εἰς τὴν γέενναν τοῦ πυρός.  
(Translation: But I say to you that everyone who is angry with his brother will be liable to judgment; whoever insults his brother will be liable to the council; and whoever says, 'You fool!' will be liable to hell of fire.)

**Translation**:
> Pues yo añado que el que se enoja contra su hermano está cometiendo el mismo delito. El que le dice “idiota” a su hermano, merece que lo lleven al juzgado. Y el que maldiga a una persona, merece ir a parar a las llamas del infierno.  
(Translation: But I say that whoever is angry with his brother is committing the same offense. Whoever says 'idiot' to his brother deserves to be brought to judgment. And whoever curses a person deserves to go to the flames of hell.)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 5:22 is generally clear, modern, and accessible, effectively conveying the seriousness of anger and insults within relationships, which aligns well with conservative Christian teachings on reconciliation and moral conduct. However, the phrase "merece ir a parar a las llamas del infierno" (deserves to go to the flames of hell) may need to be softened or refined for a more reverent tone while preserving the warning's seriousness. Overall, the translation is strong, relatable, and successfully meets the objective of engagement with the target audience.

> ―¿Pero con qué, si no tenemos más que cinco panecillos y dos pescados? (But with what, if we have only five loaves and two fish?)

The translation of MAT 14:17 effectively communicates the original meaning of the Greek text in a clear and accessible modern Spanish style. The phrasing, "¿Pero con qué, si no tenemos más que cinco panecillos y dos pescados?" (But with what, if we have only five loaves and two fish?) captures the disciples' concern and reflects their limited resources in a conversational tone, making it relatable for Latin American audiences. However, some reviewers noted a slight inconsistency in the tone, as the phrase "más que" (more than) implies a comparison that may not fully convey the original Greek's emphasis on scarcity. Suggestions included using "solamente" (only) instead of "más que" (more than) to enhance the urgency and importance of their lack. While "panecillos" (small loaves) is familiar, a recommendation was made to consider simplifying it to just "pan" (bread) for broader understanding. Additionally, while the translation is strong, it could benefit from a slight emphasis on the miraculous aspect of the event, a critical element from a conservative Christian perspective. Overall, the translation is effective, engaging, and maintains the essence of the biblical narrative.

> καὶ πᾶς ὃς ἀφῆκεν οἰκίας ἢ ἀδελφοὺς ἢ ἀδελφὰς ἢ πατέρα ἢ μητέρα ἢ γυναῖκα ἢ τέκνα ἢ ἀγροὺς ἕνεκεν τοῦ ὀνόματός μου, ἑκατονταπλασίονα λήψεται καὶ ζωὴν αἰώνιον κληρονομήσει.

(And everyone who has left houses or brothers or sisters or father or mother or wife or children or fields for my name's sake will receive a hundredfold and will inherit eternal life.)

**Translation**:
> Y cualquiera que haya dejado hogar, hermanos, hermanas, padre, madre, esposa, hijos, tierras, por seguirme, recibirá cien veces lo que haya dejado, aparte de recibir la vida eterna.

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 19:29 is effective and well-executed, maintaining the original meaning while ensuring accessibility for modern Spanish speakers, especially in Latin America. Phrases like "cualquiera que haya dejado" and "por seguirme" effectively convey the universal application and essence of the scripture, aligning well with contemporary language use. There is a commendable balance between clarity and fidelity to the original Greek. Some suggestions for improvement include simplifying the phrase "cien veces lo que haya dejado" to "cien veces más" for ease of understanding, ensuring consistency in phrasing with earlier verses, and maintaining traditional gender distinctions where applicable, such as considering "esposo" instead of "esposa". Additionally, minor adjustments could enhance the theological nuance of phrases to better reflect conservative Christian beliefs. Overall, the translation is strong and engaging, deserving a high score while remaining open to slight refinements.

> Los discípulos se fueron a la montaña de Galilea donde Jesús dijo que habría de encontrarse con ellos. (The disciples went to the mountain of Galilee where Jesus said He would meet them.)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 28:16 is clear, accessible, and effectively conveys the original message to Spanish speakers, particularly in Latin America. The phrase 'donde Jesús dijo que habría de encontrarse con ellos' (where Jesus said He would meet them) accurately captures the intent and maintains a modern tone that is relatable. While the translation is strong overall, suggestions for improvement include using a more colloquial phrasing, such as changing 'habría de encontrarse' (would meet) to 'se encontraría' (would meet), which could enhance familiarity and engagement. Additionally, incorporating a term like 'mandó' (sent) instead of 'dijo' (said) might better emphasize Jesus' directive to His disciples. Despite these minor suggestions, the translation succeeds in being both faithful to the scripture and engaging for contemporary readers.

The translation of MAT 1:5 is generally well-executed, maintaining clarity and accuracy while effectively conveying the genealogical lineage of Jesus in modern Spanish. The sentence structure is fluid, enhancing engagement and making the text accessible to contemporary readers. The preservation of names like Rahab (Rajab) and Ruth (Rut) reflects their significant roles within a conservative Christian framework. However, suggestions for improvement include using the more widely recognized forms 'Boaz' for Booz and 'Rahab' for Rajab to align with common biblical translations. Minor adjustments, such as adding conjunctions for better flow and considering traditional phrasing for parentage, would enhance clarity without compromising the translation's purpose. Overall, this translation meets the objectives well and adheres to conservative values in the presentation of the biblical text.

**MAT 5:2**: _(Grade 90.2)_

The translation of Matthew 5:2 is generally well done, capturing the essence of the original Greek text while being accessible for modern Spanish speakers, especially in Latin America. The phrase "Allí se sentó, y cuando sus discípulos se le acercaron comenzó a enseñarles:" (He sat down, and when His disciples came to Him, He began to teach them:) effectively conveys the action and context of Jesus teaching His disciples. However, there are suggestions for improvement in the flow of certain phrases. Specifically, "Allí se sentó" (There He sat down) could be replaced with "Él se sentó allí" (He sat down there) or "Entonces se sentó" (Then He sat down) for greater naturalness in conversational Spanish. Additionally, the phrase "cuando sus discípulos se le acercaron comenzó a enseñarles" (when His disciples came to Him, He began to teach them) could be rephrased to enhance fluidity. Overall, the translation meets the objective of making the scripture relatable and engaging for the audience while retaining its theological significance.

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 9:20 is generally clear and effectively conveys the meaning of the original text in a modern and accessible style for Spanish speakers, particularly in Latin America. It captures essential elements and critical details of the narrative, including the woman's condition and her action of approaching Jesus. However, minor adjustments are suggested for improved clarity and cultural resonance, such as specifying 'su' before 'manto de Jesús' (his garment) to eliminate ambiguity and considering the use of 'hemorragias' (hemorrhages) instead of 'derrame de sangre' (flow of blood) for clearer understanding among contemporary readers. Additionally, the term 'manto' (garment) could be substituted with 'túnica' (tunic) or 'vestido' (dress) for consistency with traditional biblical language while maintaining accessibility. Overall, this translation successfully maintains fidelity to the original context and intent of the scripture, although there is room for slight improvements in word choice and detail to enhance engagement for the conservative Christian audience.

> fue a Pilato y le reclamó el cuerpo de Jesús. Pilato se lo concedió.  
(Translation: He went to Pilate and requested the body of Jesus. Pilate granted it to him.)  

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 27:58 is clear and effectively communicates the meaning of the original text. The phrase 'fue a Pilato y le reclamó el cuerpo de Jesús. Pilato se lo concedió.' (He went to Pilate and requested the body of Jesus. Pilate granted it to him.) accurately conveys Joseph of Arimathea's actions and maintains the narrative integrity. However, there are suggestions for improvement: using 'pidió' (asked) instead of 'reclamó' (claimed) may present a tone that aligns better with the original request's respectful nature and enhances clarity. Overall, this is a strong translation that meets the objectives well, with only minor adjustments needed to enhance its alignment with traditional interpretations and context.

(Immediately Jesus reached out his hand and caught him, saying to him, "O you of little faith! Why did you doubt?")

> ―¡Hombre de poca fe! ¿Por qué dudaste?  
(Extending his hand, Jesus caught him and said to him: "O man of little faith! Why did you doubt?")  

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 14:31 effectively captures the essence of the original Greek text and uses modern, accessible Spanish appropriate for Latin American readers. The phrase "¡Hombre de poca fe! ¿Por qué dudaste?" accurately conveys Jesus's admonition and emotional intensity while maintaining theological integrity. Reviews highlight that the translation is clear and relatable, with a few minor suggestions for improving fluency and cultural nuances. Overall, it successfully meets the objectives set for the translation, striking a balance between accuracy and readability.

**MAT 16:19**: _(Grade 90.5)_

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 16:19 is well-executed and maintains a modern and accessible approach for Spanish-speaking audiences in Latin America. However, the phrases "la puerta que cierres en la tierra se cerrará en el cielo; y la puerta que abras en la tierra se abrirá en el cielo" (the door that you close on earth will be closed in heaven; and the door that you open on earth will be opened in heaven) could be more accurately expressed using traditional terminology such as "lo que ates" (what you bind) and "lo que desates" (what you loose) to better align with the theological implications of binding and loosing as understood in a conservative Christian context. While the translation is clear and engaging, incorporating more precise theological language would enhance clarity and understanding of the passage's significance. Overall, it meets the objective of being comprehensible and relatable while preserving important doctrinal meanings.

Overall, the translation maintains a clear and engaging tone, demonstrating a solid understanding of the source text while fulfilling the objective of making scripture more relatable for contemporary Spanish speakers. Overall, this translation aligns with the objective of making the Bible accessible and engaging for Latin American readers, accurately preserving the directness and condemnation of the original text. Minor improvements could enhance the connection to the following quote from Isaiah, but the translation remains commendable and true to the original intent.

> οἴδατε ὅτι μετὰ δύο ἡμέρας τὸ πάσχα γίνεται, καὶ ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου παραδίδοται εἰς τὸ σταυρωθῆναι.  ("You know that after two days the Passover is coming, and the Son of Man will be delivered up to be crucified.")

**Translation**:
> «Como ya saben, dentro de dos días se celebra la Pascua, y me van a traicionar y a crucificar». ("As you know, in two days the Passover is celebrated, and they are going to betray me and crucify me.")

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 26:2 is generally effective in conveying the original meaning of the Greek text while remaining accessible to a modern Spanish-speaking audience. The phrase "dentro de dos días se celebra la Pascua" accurately communicates the timing and significance of the event. However, there is a consensus among reviewers that the phrase "me van a traicionar y a crucificar" may slightly diverge from a more literal translation of the original text. The word "traicionar" could be interpreted as informal, and a more direct phrase like "seré entregado" might better reflect the solemnity of the betrayal. While the translation maintains clarity and engagement, incorporating a tone that emphasizes the seriousness of the betrayal and considering the inclusion of more biblical terminology (like "hijo del hombre" - "Son of Man") could enhance its theological accuracy. Overall, the translation achieves its purpose of making the scripture accessible, but minor adjustments could further improve its fidelity to the original text and its gravity.

**MAT 18:7**: _(Grade 91.2)_

> Οὐαὶ τῷ κόσμῳ ἀπὸ τῶν σκανδάλων· ἀνάγκη γάρ ἐστιν ἐλθεῖν τὰ σκάνδαλα· πλὴν οὐαὶ τῷ ἀνθρώπῳ ἐκείνῳ δι᾽ οὗ τὸ σκάνδαλον ἔρχεται.  
(Translation: "Woe to the world because of the scandals! It is necessary for scandals to come; but woe to the person through whom the scandal comes.")  

**Translation**:
> ¡Ay del mundo y sus maldades! La tentación es, ciertamente, inevitable, pero ¡ay de la persona que tienta!  
(Translation: "Woe to the world and its wickedness! Temptation is indeed inevitable, but woe to the person who tempts!")  

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 18:7 effectively communicates the original Greek text's meaning in a modern and accessible style. The phrase "¡Ay del mundo y sus maldades!" ("Woe to the world and its wickedness!") appropriately conveys the warning tone regarding temptation and sin, which aligns with a conservative Christian perspective on the seriousness of causing others to stumble. The expression "la tentación es, ciertamente, inevitable, pero ¡ay de la persona que tienta!" ("Temptation is indeed inevitable, but woe to the person who tempts!") accurately reflects the responsibility individuals bear not to lead others into sin. Overall, the translation is faithful to the source material, engages well with contemporary Spanish speakers, and captures both the gravity and theological implications of the scripture. Minor enhancements for clarity and flow could improve the overall quality, but this translation meets its objectives commendably.

**MAT 21:21**: _(Grade 91.2)_

**Source**:
> ἀποκριθεὶς δὲ ὁ Ἰησοῦς εἶπεν αὐτοῖς· ἀμὴν λέγω ὑμῖν, ἐὰν ἔχητε πίστιν καὶ μὴ διακριθῆτε, οὐ μόνον τὸ τῆς συκῆς ποιήσετε, ἀλλὰ κἂν τῷ ὄρει τούτῳ εἴπητε, ἄρθητι καὶ βλήθητι εἰς τὴν θάλασσαν, γενήσεται· (And Jesus answered them: Truly I say to you, if you have faith and do not doubt, you will not only do what was done to the fig tree, but even if you say to this mountain, ‘Be taken up and thrown into the sea,’ it will happen.)

**Translation**:
> Y Jesús les respondió:  (And Jesus answered them:)
> ―Pues les repito que si tienen fe y no dudan, podrán hacer cosas como esta y muchas más. (I repeat to you that if you have faith and do not doubt, you will be able to do things like this and many more.) Hasta podrán decirle al Monte de los Olivos que se quite y se arroje al mar, y los obedecerá. (You will even be able to tell the Mount of Olives to move and be thrown into the sea, and it will obey you.)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 21:21 is generally well-received, achieving an overall strong grade of 91.2. It effectively captures the essence and meaning of Jesus' teachings on faith, using modern, accessible Spanish suitable for Latin American audiences. Reviewers appreciated the engaging style and clarity of phrases such as "podrán hacer cosas como esta y muchas más" (you will be able to do things like this and many more), which conveys the power of belief. However, some suggest emphasizing the authoritative tone of 'les obedecerá' (it will obey you) to strengthen its impact. Additionally, the reference to the mountain could be more specific, with suggestions to use "este monte" (this mountain) for clarity and respect in context. Overall, the translation aligns well with the objective of making the scripture relatable without compromising its theological depth.

**MAT 10:42**: _(Grade 91.3)_

**Source**:  
> καὶ ὃς ἐὰν ποτίσῃ ἕνα τῶν μικρῶν τούτων ποτήριον ψυχροῦ μόνον εἰς ὄνομα μαθητοῦ, ἀμὴν λέγω ὑμῖν, οὐ μὴ ἀπολέσῃ τὸν μισθὸν αὐτοῦ.  
(And whoever gives one of these little ones a cup of cold water in the name of a disciple, truly I say to you, he will by no means lose his reward.)  

**Translation**:  
> Y el que le dé al más humilde de mis discípulos un vaso de agua por el simple hecho de que es mi discípulo recibirá su recompensa: esto se lo aseguro yo a ustedes.  
(And whoever gives the most humble of my disciples a cup of water for the simple reason that he is my disciple will receive his reward: this I assure you.)  

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 10:42 effectively captures the essence and intent of the original Greek text, emphasizing the importance of small acts of kindness towards Jesus' disciples and the associated rewards. It utilizes modern and accessible language that resonates with contemporary Spanish-speaking audiences in Latin America. While phrases like "por el simple hecho de que es mi discípulo" and "esto se lo aseguro yo a ustedes" effectively convey the intended meaning, some reviews suggest a more direct translation of the assurance ('ἀμὴν λέγω ὑμῖν' - "truly I say to you") and a more traditional phrasing. Additionally, the choice of "humilde" for "μικρός" (which generally means "small" or "little") has been noted as potentially narrowing the meaning of the original term, though it still reflects a commendable understanding of humility in service.
