> ὅπως γένησθε υἱοὶ τοῦ πατρὸς ὑμῶν τοῦ ἐν οὐρανοῖς, ὅτι τὸν ἥλιον αὐτοῦ ἀνατέλλει ἐπὶ πονηροὺς καὶ ἀγαθοὺς καὶ βρέχει ἐπὶ δικαίους καὶ ἀδίκους.  
(That you may be sons of your Father who is in heaven, for He makes His sun rise on the evil and on the good, and sends rain on the just and on the unjust.)

**Translation**:
> De esta forma estarán actuando como hijos de su Padre que está en el cielo, porque él da la luz del sol a los malos y a los buenos y envía la lluvia a los justos y a los injustos.  
(Thus, you will be acting as sons of your Father who is in heaven, because He gives the light of the sun to the bad and to the good and sends rain to the just and to the unjust.)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 5:45 is overall clear, accurate, and effectively communicates the original meaning. It uses modern, relatable Spanish that is accessible to a Latin American audience. Most reviewers highlighted the clarity and theological significance of God's impartiality in blessing both the good and the evil. Suggestions for improvement included simplifying the phrase "la luz del sol" to just "el sol" for a more natural sound, and emphasizing the relational aspect of being God's children and loving one's enemies, which is crucial in the context of the Sermon on the Mount. Overall, the translation meets its objectives well while allowing for minor adjustments to enhance clarity and relatability.

(*"Which indeed is the smallest of all seeds; but when it is grown, it is the greatest among herbs, and becomes a tree, so that the birds of the air come and lodge in the branches thereof."*)

(*"The mustard seed is the smallest of all seeds, but it becomes a huge tree in whose branches the birds make their nests."*)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 13:32 is generally well-received, capturing the essence of the original Greek text and using modern, accessible Spanish appropriate for a Latin American audience. The phrase "la semilla de mostaza es la más pequeña de todas las semillas, pero se convierte en un árbol enorme en cuyas ramas los pájaros hacen sus nidos" effectively conveys both the humility and transformative growth central to this parable. Reviewers noted the vivid imagery and engagement of the target audience, aligning well with conservative Christian perspectives on the message of growth in the Kingdom of Heaven. However, there are suggestions for slight improvements in metaphorical depth and nuance, particularly regarding the emphasis on spiritual transformation and growth in faith. Overall, it is a strong translation with minor room for enhancements.

**MAT 23:23**: _(Grade 92.3)_

**Source**:
> Οὐαὶ ὑμῖν, γραμματεῖς καὶ Φαρισαῖοι ὑποκριταί, ὅτι ἀποδεκατοῦτε τὸ ἡδύοσμον καὶ τὸ ἄνηθον καὶ τὸ κύμινον, καὶ ἀφήκατε τὰ βαρύτερα τοῦ νόμου, τὴν κρίσιν καὶ τὸν ἔλεον καὶ τὴν πίστιν· ταῦτα δὲ ἔδει ποιῆσαι κἀκεῖνα μὴ ἀφιέναι.  
> (Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you tithe mint and dill and cumin, and have neglected the weightier matters of the law: justice and mercy and faith. These you ought to have done, without neglecting the others.)

**Translation**:

> ("Woe to you, hypocritical Pharisees and scribes! For you tithe even the smallest leaf of garden mint but forget the most important thing, which is to do justice, have mercy, and faith. Yes, you must tithe, but you cannot neglect what is even more important.")

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 23:23 effectively captures the essence of the original Greek text while maintaining clarity and accessibility for Spanish speakers. Key phrases like "ay de ustedes" ("woe to you") and the emphasis on justice, mercy, and faith are well-expressed, aligning with conservative Christian values. There are minor suggestions for improvement, such as refining the order of 'justicia' (justice), 'misericordia' (mercy), and 'fe' (faith) for theological clarity and possibly adjusting the phrasing "aun más importante" ("even more important") for better impact. Overall, the translation meets its objectives well, balancing the practice of tithing with the greater moral responsibilities highlighted in the passage.

> οὐδὲ καίουσι λύχνον καὶ τιθέασιν αὐτὸν ὑπὸ τὸν μόδιον, ἀλλ᾽ ἐπὶ τὴν λυχνίαν, καὶ λάμπει πᾶσι τοῖς ἐν τῇ οἰκίᾳ.  (Nor do they light a lamp and put it under a basket, but on a stand, and it gives light to all in the house.)

**Translation**:
> Nadie enciende una lámpara para esconderla bajo un cajón, sino que la pone en alto para que alumbre a todos los que están en la casa.  (No one lights a lamp to hide it under a basket, but rather puts it on a stand to give light to all who are in the house.)

**Combined Review**:
The translation of MAT 5:15 effectively captures the essence of the original Greek text, presenting a clear and accessible interpretation for Spanish speakers, especially in Latin America. Most reviewers agree that the phrasing 'Nadie enciende una lámpara para esconderla bajo un cajón, sino que la pone en alto para que alumbre a todos los que están en la casa' conveys the intended meaning well. However, there are suggestions for improvement, specifically regarding the term 'cajón', which could be perceived as slightly informal. Alternative phrases like 'bajo un recipiente' were proposed to enhance clarity while maintaining the translation's accessibility and theological accuracy. Overall, the translation successfully emphasizes the importance of being a visible light in the world, aligning well with conservative Christian values.
